node.title: CST_Storage_26
node.doctext:
This is a storage node for CST reviews. Reviews are moved here from our working area in [CST_Chat].

This archive begins on , When it's full we'll move to [CST_Storage_27].

See also CST Storage collabs [CST_Storage_1|1] - [CST_Storage_25|25].

Batch Processed on:
=================================================
Batch Processed on: 28 Feb 2008

Writeup Title:[Falling in Love Again]
Author:[eyeofthebeholder]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No
Original Author's Permission received?: No.
Quoted content less than 33%: .008%,.01%, .03%,.01%, .02%
Compliance Assessment:Yes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:2008-01-21@21:12 [eyeofthebeholder] says Hi there! I wonder if you'd give me the stamp of approval for my newest [Falling in Love Again]...I used numerous bits of lyric from songs, but they are tiny, so I don't think it's much of a problem. Thanks!
Hello eyeofthebeholder, Your write up [Falling in Love Again] passes with flying colors! You may add the [CST Approved] tag if you like. :)

Writeup Title:[Dictionary of Sexology]
Author:[Eraser_]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: Yes.
Quoted content less than 33%: NA
Compliance Assessment: Yes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:

2007-12-09@17:30 [Lord Brawl] says [Dictionary of Sexology] could use a refresh, but the noder has fled. Perhaps we can get permission to move it to [everyone]?

Sent an email to everything@hawknetworks.com:
Hello Eraser_,
Lord_Brawl has asked me to contact you via the [Content_Salvage] account and was wondering if we might be able to move the [Dictionary of Sexology] to the [everyone] account for maintenance purposes. We would need the copyright holder’s permission to do that as well as yours.
Happy New Years!
Lolo
Hi Lord Brawl, Just a note to let you know I tried contacting the author of the [Dictionary of Sexology] by email. :)

Writeup Title:[Lipstick in a Concentration Camp]
Author:[fallensparks]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: No.
Quoted content less than 33%:91%
Compliance Assessment: No.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:2007-11-28@16:51 [kthejoker] says did you kill that [lipstick] node by [etgar] about the Holocaust / Red Cross thing over copyright issues? If so, there's a new one, [Lipstick in a Concentration Camp].
Hello fallensparks, Unfortunately E2 cannot keep copyrighted material in its database. This particular article is copyrighted to the [Guardian] as “Lipstick in Belsen” (Lieutenant Colonel Mervin Willett Gonin), Guardian, 13 June 1998. This is such awesome information we would really like to see it meet fair use to put it in the database. To do that copyrighted work cannot exceed the original content by 33%. At this time the copyrighted work is 98%.If you would like to update it and resubmit it you may want to read through the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material] for some suggestions and ideas. If you have any questions please feel free to contact me and I’ll be happy to help :)

This particular article is copyrighted to the [Guadian] as “Lipstick in Belsen” (Lieutenant Colonel Mervin Willett Gonin), Guardian, 13 June 1998. This is such awesome information we would really like to see it meet fair use to keep it in the database. To do that copyrighted work cannot exceed the original content by 33%. At this time the copyrighted work is 98%.You may want to read through the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material] for some suggestions and ideas. Please let me know what you would like to do. If I haven’t heard from you in [November 17,2007|10 days] I’ll assume you have decided not to update it and it will be removed. It will be available in your [node heaven] and it can always update it at another time. If you have any questions please feel free to contact me and I’ll be happy to help :)
Hello etgar, unfortunately this writeup doesn't appear to be compliant with the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material|E2 Copyright Policy] and has to be removed. If you'd like to update it for compliance and repost, I'd be glad to help you with suggestions and ideas.

Hi Bob, All’s well here. :) It’s just a bit over on the lyrics at 282. The cutoff is 250. I’m getting 35% of the write up as being quoted text too. I think if you tweak a couple of lines, which may put it on the mark. Love lolo, da infamous content guru-ess.

Writeup Title:[Seitan ]
Author:[sensei]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: No.
Quoted content less than 33%: 3%
Compliance Assessment: Yes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2007-10-07@14:49[ XWiz] says Hey Lometa - can you do me a favour and give me a second opinion. I was trawling through the daylogs and I found this one by [Vagary] under [May 12, 2002] - the one about seitan and plagiarism. Check out Sensei's node and about halfway down the article listed. They are the same, but Sensei has changed the odd word or two. I'm not sure whether it constitutes plagiarism or whether to just ignore it. Hence... your advice, please. :)
Hi XWiz! Thanks for bringing this to my attention. sensei once had a node called [The Everything Dishonest Scholarship Problem] which is long gone, but still he acknowledged that he too was guilty of some falsities. I have yet to find one though. He had also published a number of translations from Japanese to English and well aware of copyrights. He was very clever with [seitan]. In the US, recipes enjoy [US Copyright for Recipes|unique latitude] in that lists of ingredients are not subject to copyright. Tossing out the list of ingredients and the sentences he wrote in his own words leaves a whopping 3% of the words borrowed from the website [Vagary] references. Since sensei was a cook we can’t say where he got his original text. It could be from this web site or he could have gotten it from his own copy of the cookbook. It’s [CST approved]. :)

Writeup Title: [Words and Expressions Commonly Misused]
Author: [danlowlite]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: Yes
Original Author's Permission received?: No
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Yes
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2007.07.13 at 02:16 OldMiner says I was cleaning out my old messages from years back, and I found I had messaged someone about Words and Expressions Commonly Misused because it reference 'Rule 13' without any explanation. It turns out it's a copy of 1918 White's Elements of Style (before there was a Strunk attached). It should probably have attribution added, in addition to a proper CST review, if possible. To be fair, I'm biased -- I don't like Strunk and White. Mostly White.
Hi there, Good news, this writeup appears to be fully compliant with the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material|E2 Copyright Policy] via Public Domain. I added a citation and [CST Approved] tag.

Hi there, Bad news I'm afraid. This writeup doesn't appear to be compliant with the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material|E2 Copyright Policy]. The original is © 2000 by Jurisdictionary Foundation, Inc. (in trust for the Estate of Hon. Harry Fogle), who state: "Please do not use or reproduce without permission and proper credit to the author." Unless you have received the required permission I'll have to remove the writeup.
http://1215.org/lawnotes/lawnotes/jesustrial.htm
2007-06-21 (5.8 hr) Protector of Mankind says ya The Trial of Jesus, I understand. Too bad. :) its very interesting.
Yes, it is an interesting perspective. You may be able to get permission from Jurisdictionary to republish if you ask.
Tc = 4275, Tq = 4275, %q= 100%

Writeup Title: [By the Waters of Babylon]
Author: [Kizor]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: No
Original Author's Permission received?: Yes
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Yes
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2007.06.17 at 17:22 witchiepoo says liveforever pointed out that his identical write-up was axed for copywrite issues, would you like to take this one? By the Waters of Babylon by Kizor. He says it is in public domain.
Hi there, I've been asked to review this for [E2 Copyright Changes|E2 copyright compliance]. The wu mentions that the work is Public Domain, but it was first published in 1937, so I'm not clear on why it's PD. Could you please explain?
2007.06.18 at 22:29 Kizor says What I was acting on was, on reflection, tacit approval: By The Waters of Babylon has been undisturbed on Wikisource for two years now, categorized and monitored, and you know how hard those folks come down on copyrights. Wikisource explicitly forbids fair use. You know copyrights and E2 better than me, but looking at the link you gave and the external links from it I got the impression that to be in copyright, the story would've had to been renewed at the end of the original term of protection, 28 years, at which point Benet had been dead for a long time. (I wouldn't trust my own judgement on this, FYI.) If necessary, I can truncate the w/u to remove the story entirely and replace with a Wikisource link, but it'll be a pity, since I'm quite pleased with my experimental softlinking.
Thanks for getting back to me. I like the writeup, and the story itself, but based on what I've seem thus far I don't see why the story would be PD. The WikiSource page is perplexing because they ARE very careful. I think I could give your wu a pass if we prepared a carefully worded citation indicating Wiki as the source. Would you be okay with that?
2007.06.19 at 17:34 Kizor says That would be utterly satisfactory. How would one be crafted? I'm not experienced with creating citations.
I took the liberty of adding an appropriate note at the bottom of your wu. If you're okay with that we're all done. Cheers.

Source Notes
By the Waters of Babylon is reproduced on E2 courtesy of Wikisource.org
Citation: Wikisource contributors, "By the Waters of Babylon," Wikisource, The Free Library, http://en.wikisource.org/w/index.php?title=By_the_Waters_of_Babylon&oldid=386071 (accessed June 19, 2007). Per the WikiSource.org licensing terms, this is [CST Approved] via the original author's permission.
Tc = 6342, Tq = 5762, %q= 91%

Writeup Title:[World's Shortest Pessimistic Poem]
Author:[shrimpo]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: No
Quoted content less than 33%: 50
Compliance Assessment: No.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:2007-05-26@5:22 [Jack]says so, this might be silly but... World's Shortest Pessimistic Poem this]is a copyright violation, isn't it? I mean, it'd need four words of original text appended to the bottom to clear policy, but...
Hello shrimpo, Unfortunately this poem was publish in “The Maple Laugh Forever: An Anthology of Canadian Comic Poetry” (1981) and because of the [E2 copyright changes] we can no longer keep it in the database. If you would like to update this and resubmit it you may want to read through the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material] for suggestions and ideas. If you have any questions please feel free to contact an editor or myself and we will be happy to assist. :)
